Driver, Lewin and Berkowitz to Uphold Honor of Class—Junior Representatives Not Yet Selected.

The seniors held their debating
tryouts Thursday, February 19,
and selected the three men who
are to represent the class in the
traditional senior-junior debate.
Out of the eight men who came
out for the tryouts, the following
team was selected: Warren M.
Driver, chairman and second
speaker; John H. Lewin, first
speaker; Berkowitz, rebuttal, and
John R. Bartels, alternate. There
may be some change in the order
of speakers, which, if made, will
be announced later. The seniors
are well represented in this team,
for all of those selected are experienced men. Lewin won the Adams medal during his sophomore
year and during his junior year
was a member of the junior team
and the 'Varsity team, both of
which were victorious. Bartels
was also a member of the victorious junior team last year, while
Berkowitz won his spurs as a
'Varsity debater two years ago.
Driver gained his experience as a
member of the victorious junior
and 'Varsity teams and as winner
of the Tocqueville medal of 1919.
The junior team has not yet
been selected.

The audience was afforded a
vivid picture of this method of signalling by a painting which had
been set up on the table. It was
a scene on the battle front in
France. There was a small hole
punched in the picture, through
which was thrown a light, entirely
invisible to the naked eye. By
holding a red lens to the eye, one
saw the light, which showed as a
tiny spot on the painted horizon.
When it was ,switched off and on,
the resemblance to a signal apparatus was made very effective.
The possibilities for the use of
the ultra-violet light in aeronautics are very great, both for running lights on planes and for signals at the landing places, which
must be kept dark if enemy planes
are about.
Dr. Wood showed many interest experiments, and illustrated
how the ultra-violet light could
be used for other purposes, such
as detecting secret writing and
producing stage effects.

In response to the desires of a
large number of graduate and undergraduate students, the Johns
Hopkins Scientific Association announces a lecture by Prof. Joseph
S. Ames on "Einstein's Theory of
Gravitation," to be given on Tuesday, March 2, at 12.25 P. M., in
the C. E. auditorium.
THE NEws-LErrER recently published an article on the same subject by Professor Ames and the result was that the interest and
curiosity for more knowledge of
the theory was further aroused.
Those who attended the lecture by
Professor Bauer on a related subject remember the disappointment
they had in not hearing much
about the Einstein theory.
Professor Ames was persuaded
to give this lecture because of the
great importance attached to the
Einstein theory. Most students
of science have heard much talk
about it, but even their instructors lay no claims to an intimate
knowledge or understanding of
the theory. Professor Ames will
talk about the Einstein theory of
gravitation from the point of view
of its origin and its meaning.
All students and other individuals, whether connected with the
University or not, are welcome to
attend the lecture.
The Italian Circle Reorganized.

The Italian circle, which has
been inactive at Hopkins for over
a year, has been re-established.
It was originally started by Dr.
M. P. Brush, who was its first
president, and upon his leaving
the University the leadership was
given over to Dr. Kirby Flower
Smith, who held this position until his death last year. With his
death, the circle went out of existence, and it is just recently that
it has been reorganized by Mr.
Schiavo, a graduate student at the
University.
Membership is extended to anyone who can speak and write
Italian and is interested in Italian affairs. Meetings are held
twice a month at 719 Park avenue, the home of its former president, Dr. Smith. At the last
meeting, which took place on Monday, the twenty-third of this
month, Mr. Schiavo gave a lecture
on Vittorio Locchi, an Italian
poet who was killed in the war.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, FEBRUARY 24, 1920.

HOPKINS BUILDINGS INSPECTED
"Safety First" Committees Make Reports
—Students Asked to Aid in Prevention of Risk.

As was stated in a recent issue
of THE NEWS-LETTER, a movement
has been started at Hopkins by
President Goodnow to hunt out
and do away with any conditions
around the University which
might be dangerous in starting a
fire or causing an accident. In
the fires that have taken place in
Baltimore this year. Johns Hopkins has suffered severely, and it
seems no stone should be left unturned which would help in preserving our fine new buildings.
The plan, which has already
been put into effect, is to have
committees of students, with a
member of the faculty as chairman, make a monthly inspection
of each building and report any
firetraps, carelessness by students
or janitors, and similar conditions
which would increase the fire and
accident risk at the University.
Dr. Goodnow has undertaken to
see that these recommendations
are put into immediate effect.
The three committees recently
appointed have each made their
first inspection tour, although the
report of the Civil Engineering
Building is the only one ready for
publication. A few items from
this report may help to show some
of the conditions,which all should
strive to right.
Report of the Safety Committee
for the Civil Engineering

AT OTHER COLLEGES
Middlebury College.

Middlebury College has received
a gift of $65,000, which is to be
used for athletics. The idea of
the donor is to revive the old
Roman tradition of a sound mind
in a sound body.
Yale.

Yale has adopted a plan whereby all important campus events
will be recorded by the motion
picture camera. The films will be
the property of the several classes,
and will be shown at reunions.
University of Buenos Aires.

The students of the University
of Buenos Aires are permitted to
vote as to which members of the
faculty shall be retained.
Columbia.

The freshmen recently took the
song test at Columbia. Those
knowing the songs were presented
with a little green card, but those
who were lacking the memory
work had their hands (lipped in
iodine.
Hobart.

Hobart College is the first
American college to receive a 77millimeter field piece from the
French government. It will be
kept on exhibition as a perpetual
memorial to the men who were
killed in the war.
University of Michigan.

The University of Michigan has
announced a raise in salary for
professors ranging from $300 to
$800. The minimum salary was
set at $1,500.

When Alexander died before his prime,
His men were overwhelmed with dismay,
Incredulous that he was dead, and they
Without him In a lonely, alien clime.
But though revived from this, no after time
Could quench or lessen, soften or allay,
Their sorrow for the loss of half his day,
The years that would have made him more
sublime.

So, when death robbed me of my best-loved
friend,
At first my own grief choked me through
my tears
To lose the comradeship we two had
shared;
But now I mourn what nothing can amend,
Mankind's lost harvest of his unlived years.

Paintings of Professors Received by
University at Commemoration E xercises—Dr. Ir tench :peaks.

The three portraits acquired by
the University during the exercises were of the late Prof. Kirby
Flower Smith of Dr. John Whitridge Williams, professor of obstetrics and dean of the medical
faculty and of Dr. Florence Rena
Sabin, professor of histology. They
were presented by Profs. John C.
French, William H. Welch and W.
H. Howell, respectively.
Dr. French's speech of presentation was as follows:
"Mr. President: On behalf of the
former students, colleagues and
friends of the late Kirby Flower
Smith, I have the honor to present
to you, and through you to the
University, this portrait. We
should certainly, in due time, have
asked Professor Smith to sit for
his portrait, but while such a
time seemed, in view of his youthful spirit, yet far distant, he was
taken from us with tragic suddenness at the height of his usefulness. Fortunately excellent photographs were available, and from
these the artist has achieved a
likeness worthy to be treasured
among the memorials of our illustrious dead.

dreamer-like qualities. When the
war came, he saw service in the
Dardanelles campaign.
Masefield began his literary
career as a novelist, publishing
three novels. Then followed a collection of tales and sea stories,
plays, and then poetry. The tragedies of Masefield exhibit a
dreamer's idealism. "Tragedy is
inherent in the characters. It is
not a struggle against a moral
law, but a refusal to relinquish
ideal beauty which causes the
tragedy. There is no relief from
the tragical and emotional fervor." The poetry of Masefield includes: "Sea Poems," "Salt-water
Poems and Ballads," "The Dauber," "The Everlasting Mercy,"
"The Widow of Bye Street," and
"Reynard, the Fox." "The Everlasting Mercy" reveals the vivid
and intense side of Masefield's
style coupled with his lyric powers. He is a realist, singing of
"dirt and dross and the scum of
the earth," coloring the whole, as
Wordsworth did, with his imagination.

Driver, Lewin and Berkowitz to Uphold Honor of Class—Junior Representatives Not Yet Selected.

The seniors held their debating
tryouts Thursday, February 19,
and selected the three men who
are to represent the class in the
traditional senior-junior debate.
Out of the eight men who came
out for the tryouts, the following
team was selected: Warren M.
Driver, chairman and second
speaker; John H. Lewin, first
speaker; Berkowitz, rebuttal, and
John R. Bartels, alternate. There
may be some change in the order
of speakers, which, if made, will
be announced later. The seniors
are well represented in this team,
for all of those selected are experienced men. Lewin won the Adams medal during his sophomore
year and during his junior year
was a member of the junior team
and the 'Varsity team, both of
which were victorious. Bartels
was also a member of the victorious junior team last year, while
Berkowitz won his spurs as a
'Varsity debater two years ago.
Driver gained his experience as a
member of the victorious junior
and 'Varsity teams and as winner
of the Tocqueville medal of 1919.
The junior team has not yet
been selected.

The audience was afforded a
vivid picture of this method of signalling by a painting which had
been set up on the table. It was
a scene on the battle front in
France. There was a small hole
punched in the picture, through
which was thrown a light, entirely
invisible to the naked eye. By
holding a red lens to the eye, one
saw the light, which showed as a
tiny spot on the painted horizon.
When it was ,switched off and on,
the resemblance to a signal apparatus was made very effective.
The possibilities for the use of
the ultra-violet light in aeronautics are very great, both for running lights on planes and for signals at the landing places, which
must be kept dark if enemy planes
are about.
Dr. Wood showed many interest experiments, and illustrated
how the ultra-violet light could
be used for other purposes, such
as detecting secret writing and
producing stage effects.

In response to the desires of a
large number of graduate and undergraduate students, the Johns
Hopkins Scientific Association announces a lecture by Prof. Joseph
S. Ames on "Einstein's Theory of
Gravitation," to be given on Tuesday, March 2, at 12.25 P. M., in
the C. E. auditorium.
THE NEws-LErrER recently published an article on the same subject by Professor Ames and the result was that the interest and
curiosity for more knowledge of
the theory was further aroused.
Those who attended the lecture by
Professor Bauer on a related subject remember the disappointment
they had in not hearing much
about the Einstein theory.
Professor Ames was persuaded
to give this lecture because of the
great importance attached to the
Einstein theory. Most students
of science have heard much talk
about it, but even their instructors lay no claims to an intimate
knowledge or understanding of
the theory. Professor Ames will
talk about the Einstein theory of
gravitation from the point of view
of its origin and its meaning.
All students and other individuals, whether connected with the
University or not, are welcome to
attend the lecture.
The Italian Circle Reorganized.

The Italian circle, which has
been inactive at Hopkins for over
a year, has been re-established.
It was originally started by Dr.
M. P. Brush, who was its first
president, and upon his leaving
the University the leadership was
given over to Dr. Kirby Flower
Smith, who held this position until his death last year. With his
death, the circle went out of existence, and it is just recently that
it has been reorganized by Mr.
Schiavo, a graduate student at the
University.
Membership is extended to anyone who can speak and write
Italian and is interested in Italian affairs. Meetings are held
twice a month at 719 Park avenue, the home of its former president, Dr. Smith. At the last
meeting, which took place on Monday, the twenty-third of this
month, Mr. Schiavo gave a lecture
on Vittorio Locchi, an Italian
poet who was killed in the war.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, FEBRUARY 24, 1920.

HOPKINS BUILDINGS INSPECTED
"Safety First" Committees Make Reports
—Students Asked to Aid in Prevention of Risk.

As was stated in a recent issue
of THE NEWS-LETTER, a movement
has been started at Hopkins by
President Goodnow to hunt out
and do away with any conditions
around the University which
might be dangerous in starting a
fire or causing an accident. In
the fires that have taken place in
Baltimore this year. Johns Hopkins has suffered severely, and it
seems no stone should be left unturned which would help in preserving our fine new buildings.
The plan, which has already
been put into effect, is to have
committees of students, with a
member of the faculty as chairman, make a monthly inspection
of each building and report any
firetraps, carelessness by students
or janitors, and similar conditions
which would increase the fire and
accident risk at the University.
Dr. Goodnow has undertaken to
see that these recommendations
are put into immediate effect.
The three committees recently
appointed have each made their
first inspection tour, although the
report of the Civil Engineering
Building is the only one ready for
publication. A few items from
this report may help to show some
of the conditions,which all should
strive to right.
Report of the Safety Committee
for the Civil Engineering

AT OTHER COLLEGES
Middlebury College.

Middlebury College has received
a gift of $65,000, which is to be
used for athletics. The idea of
the donor is to revive the old
Roman tradition of a sound mind
in a sound body.
Yale.

Yale has adopted a plan whereby all important campus events
will be recorded by the motion
picture camera. The films will be
the property of the several classes,
and will be shown at reunions.
University of Buenos Aires.

The students of the University
of Buenos Aires are permitted to
vote as to which members of the
faculty shall be retained.

Junior Class Meeting.

At a meeting of the Junior
Class, held last Wednesday, R.
Graham Heiner was chosen for
editor-in-chief of the 1921 Hullabaloo. At the same meeting the
following men were nominated for
the office of business manager:
Bascom Kennady, Bartus Trew,
F. F. Bramble and Norman Keyes.
The election of the business manager will take place at the next
meeting of the class. The editorin-chief and business manager will
go ahead with preparations for
the annual, and the rest of the
board will be elected at a later
date.

When Alexander died before his prime,
His men were overwhelmed with dismay,
Incredulous that he was dead, and they
Without him In a lonely, alien clime.
But though revived from this, no after time
Could quench or lessen, soften or allay,
Their sorrow for the loss of half his day,
The years that would have made him more
sublime.

So, when death robbed me of my best-loved
friend,
At first my own grief choked me through
my tears
To lose the comradeship we two had
shared;
But now I mourn what nothing can amend,
Mankind's lost harvest of his unlived years.
The work for which he had but Just
prepared.
—From Johns Hopkins Alumni Magazine.

"Our purpose in presenting this
portrait to the University is twofold. It is, in the first place, a
tribute of regard and affection for
the memory of a man who, beyond
most men, laid hold upon the
hearts of those whose fortune it
was to know him. In this act, we
lay upon his grave a slight, but
deeply sincere, token of the feelings which we all share. In the
second place, Mr. President, it is
our wish by this means to keep
alive the spirit and the influence
qf this brilliant member of the
University family. Over the door
that leads from the reading-room
to the store of books which he
knew and loved is a space fitted
to receive an oil painting. Here
we would hang this portrait, that
future generations of students who
give their hours to the study of
humane letters may hold in honored memory the name of Kirby
Flower Smith."

Paintings of Professors Received by
University at Commemoration E xercises—Dr. Ir tench :peaks.

The three portraits acquired by
the University during the exercises were of the late Prof. Kirby
Flower Smith of Dr. John Whitridge Williams, professor of obstetrics and dean of the medical
faculty and of Dr. Florence Rena
Sabin, professor of histology. They
were presented by Profs. John C.
French, William H. Welch and W.
H. Howell, respectively.
Dr. French's speech of presentation was as follows:
"Mr. President: On behalf of the
former students, colleagues and
friends of the late Kirby Flower
Smith, I have the honor to present
to you, and through you to the
University, this portrait. We
should certainly, in due time, have
asked Professor Smith to sit for
his portrait, but while such a
time seemed, in view of his youthful spirit, yet far distant, he was
taken from us with tragic suddenness at the height of his usefulness. Fortunately excellent photographs were available, and from
these the artist has achieved a
likeness worthy to be treasured
among the memorials of our illustrious dead.

dreamer-like qualities. When the
war came, he saw service in the
Dardanelles campaign.
Masefield began his literary
career as a novelist, publishing
three novels. Then followed a collection of tales and sea stories,
plays, and then poetry. The tragedies of Masefield exhibit a
dreamer's idealism. "Tragedy is
inherent in the characters. It is
not a struggle against a moral
law, but a refusal to relinquish
ideal beauty which causes the
tragedy. There is no relief from
the tragical and emotional fervor." The poetry of Masefield includes: "Sea Poems," "Salt-water
Poems and Ballads," "The Dauber," "The Everlasting Mercy,"
"The Widow of Bye Street," and
"Reynard, the Fox." "The Everlasting Mercy" reveals the vivid
and intense side of Masefield's
style coupled with his lyric powers. He is a realist, singing of
"dirt and dross and the scum of
the earth," coloring the whole, as
Wordsworth did, with his imagination.
